description: From Middle English ynneside; equivalent to in- +‎ side.

Compare German Innenseite (“inside”), Danish inderside (“inside”), Swedish insida (“inside”), Dutch binnenzijde (“inside”), German Low German Binnensied, Binnersied (“inside”), Saterland Frisian Binnersiede (“inside”).

adjectives.description: inside (comparative more inside, superlative most inside)

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to the inner surface, limit or boundary.
examples: The inside surface of the cup is unpainted.

entries.meaning: Nearer to the interior or centre of something.
examples: Because of the tighter bend, it's harder to run in an inside lane.
All the window seats were occupied, so she took an inside seat.

entries.meaning: Originating from, arranged by, or being someone inside an organisation.
examples: The reporter had received inside information about the forthcoming takeover.
The robbery was planned by the security guard: it was an inside job.
They wanted to know the inside story behind the celebrity's fall from grace.

entries.meaning: (of a person) Legally married to or related to (e.g. born in wedlock to), and/or residing with, a specified other person (parent, child, or partner); (of a marriage, relationship, etc) existing between two such people.
examples: Antonym: outside

entries.meaning: (baseball, of a pitch) Toward the batter as it crosses home plate.
examples: The first pitch is ... just a bit inside.

entries.meaning: At or towards or the left-hand side of the road if one drives on the left, or right-hand side if one drives on the right.
examples: the inside lane of the motorway

adverbs.description: inside (comparative more inside, superlative most inside)

definitionGroups.group: Within or towards the interior of something; within the scope or limits of something (a place), especially a building.

examples: He spent ten years inside, doing a stretch for burglary.
It was snowing, so the children stayed inside.

entries.meaning: Intimately, secretly; without expressing what one is feeling or thinking.
examples: Are you laughing at us inside?
The inside of the building has been extensively restored.

entries.meaning: The left-hand side of a road if one drives on the left, or right-hand side if one drives on the right.
examples: On a motorway, you should never pass another vehicle on the inside.

entries.meaning: The side of a curved road, racetrack etc. that has the shorter arc length; the side of a racetrack nearer the interior of the course or some other point of reference.
examples: The car in front drifted wide on the bend, so I darted up the inside to take the lead.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) (in the plural) The interior organs of the body, especially the guts.
examples: Eating that stuff will damage your insides.

entries.meaning: (dated, UK, colloquial) A passenger within a coach or carriage, as distinguished from one upon the outside.
examples: So down thy hill, romantic Ashbourne, glides / The Derby dilly, carrying three insides.

entries.meaning: (slang) The inside scoop; information known only to certain involved people.
examples: Anyone got the inside on the new ratings? The book is out.

entries.meaning: Within the interior of something, closest to the center or to a specific point of reference.
examples: He placed the letter inside the envelope.
The job was finished inside two weeks.
